channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2020 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump's Disinfectant Remarks Prompt Warnings
item.description: Several states take tentative steps to reopen businesses. The Navy recommended reinstating the captain of an aircraft carrier who had sought help as the virus spread on his ship.

item.title: Coronavirus in New Mexico: How One of the Poorest States Averted a Steep Death Toll
item.description: New Mexico showed how a state can fight the coronavirus with aggressive social distancing, free testing and scientific expertise. But contagion threats are building.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.media:credit: Eddie Moore/The Albuquerque Journal, via Associated Press
item.media:description: New Mexico’s governor, Michelle Lujan Grisham, moved quickly to guarantee free coronavirus testing for people in the state, including those not showing symptoms.

item.title: Coronavirus Has Freed Inmates From Jail, Angering Some Victims
item.description: More people are being released as outbreaks spread behind bars. But there is a growing conflict over who should be let out.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:credit: Whitney Curtis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jails are setting free thousands of inmates to slow the coronavirus’s spread behind bars. Anthony Cromwell Jr. was released from the Medium Security Institution in St. Louis.

item.title: ICE Detention Centers Approved in California Farm Town
item.description: Two privately run state prisons in the town of McFarland, many of whose residents are undocumented field workers, will be converted to hold immigrants.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Jenna Schoenefeld for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of the two privately run state prisons in McFarland, Calif., that will become federal immigration detention centers.

item.title: Trump’s Temporary Halt to Immigration is Part of Broader Plan, Stephen Miller Says
item.description: “The first and most important thing is to turn off the faucet of new immigrant labor — mission accomplished,’’ Mr. Miller told conservatives allies, according to an audio recording.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Stephen Miller, a senior adviser to President Trump, said that the executive order, while temporary, would have long-lasting effects.

item.title: Philip Kahn, 100, Dies; Spanish Flu Took His Twin a Century Ago
item.description: Aware of the irony of dying during a pandemic, he said history repeats itself. A family member called the brothers “pandemic bookends.”
item.dc:creator: Katharine Q. Seelye
item.media:description: Philip Kahn. “When he started coughing, he knew he might have it, and he knew the irony of what was going on.”

item.title: Hawaii to Visitors: We’ll Pay You to Leave
item.description: Visitors who break Hawaii’s 14-day quarantine rule may get an unwelcome gift: A free flight home.
item.dc:creator: Elaine Glusac
item.media:credit: Marco Garcia for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Honolulu beach before the coronavirus.

item.title: F.D.A. Warns of Heart Problems From Malaria Drugs Used for Coronavirus
item.description: The drugs, hydroxychloroquine and chloroquine, have been repeatedly promoted by President Trump. But they should be used only in clinical trials or hospitals, the agency said.
item.dc:creator: Denise Grady
item.category: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases
Biomedical Advanced Research and Development Authority
item.media:description: Dr. Stephen Hahn, the F.D.A. commissioner, speaking during a White House coronavirus briefing last month.

item.title: Islamic Center Damaged in ‘Suspicious’ Fire at Start of Ramadan
item.description: The police said the fire, at the Islamic Center of Cape Girardeau in Missouri, was being investigated as possible arson.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Crews responded after a fire broke out on Friday at the Islamic Center of Cape Girardeau in Missouri.

item.title: Kenneth Saunders III, Civic Leader with a Mediating Touch, Dies at 43
item.description: He joined his first local board at 18 and never stopped trying to improve his suburban Atlanta community. Mr. Saunders died of the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson
item.media:description: Kenneth Saunders III served on boards and associations in suburban Atlanta, part of his dedication to improving life for his neighbors.

item.title: Joe Biden Steps Up Warnings of Possible Trump Disruption of 2020 Election
item.description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. has increasingly speculated that President Trump may try to delay or disrupt the election in some way, sending a warning signal that attempts to frame the president as desperate.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.media:description: Early polls have showed President Trump is vulnerable in several key battleground states, which could imperil his re-election.

item.title: Durham Inquiry Includes Scrutiny of a Media Leak
item.description: The attorney general has suggested that the Justice Department review of the Russia investigation has uncovered “troubling” findings without going into details.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman, Julian E. Barnes and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: The F.B.I. headquarters in Washington. John H. Durham is leading an investigation into the bureau’s handling of the Trump-Russia investigation.

item.title: Navy Leaders Recommend Reinstating Roosevelt Captain Fired Over Virus Warning
item.description: Capt. Brett E. Crozier, who was removed from command after sending a letter pleading for help to fight the coronavirus on his aircraft carrier, was largely cleared after Navy review.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper, Eric Schmitt and Thomas Gibbons-Neff
item.media:description: Capt. Brett E. Crozier sent a letter pleading for help after a coronavirus outbreak on the carrier Theodore Roosevelt.

item.title: Trump Speech to Bring 1,000 West Point Cadets Back to Campus
item.description: The president’s off-again, on-again speech in June will bring back cadets who had scattered across the country to help counter the coronavirus.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Annie Karni
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: The commencement ceremony last year at the Military Academy in West Point, N.Y.

item.title: Madison Protests: Wisconsin Sees Largest Gathering Against Stay-at-Home Orders
item.description: The protest was one of the nation’s largest gatherings to date to condemn lockdown orders enacted by state and local governments.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Kay Nolan
item.media:credit: Lauren Justice for The New York Times
item.media:description: People protested Gov. Tony Evers’s extended stay-at-home order at the Capitol in Madison, Wis., on Friday.

item.title: Biden Will Fund-Raise With D.N.C. and His Appointee Will Lead the Committee
item.description: Joe Biden’s presidential campaign is beginning to consolidate control over the Democratic National Committee and will have the ability to raise badly needed cash.
item.dc:creator: Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher
item.media:description: Mary Beth Cahill managed John Kerry’s presidential campaign in 2004. She will now serve as chief executive of the Democratic National Committee.

item.title: Opposed to Bailouts, but in This Case Willing to Take One
item.description: Some conservative nonprofit groups are seeking financial help to weather the coronavirus crisis. Some liberal organizations are putting aside different qualms to make the same request.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth P. Vogel and Lisa Lerer
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally last year sponsored by FreedomWorks. One arm of the conservative organization is seeking aid from the coronavirus relief legislation despite its opposition to bailouts.

item.title: Trump’s Suggestion That Disinfectants Could Be Used to Treat Coronavirus Prompts Aggressive Pushback
item.description: Responding to the criticism from public health officials around the country, the president said he was playing a trick on reporters.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers, Christine Hauser, Alan Yuhas and Maggie Haberman
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Jeffrey Greenberg/Universal Images Group, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Reckitt Benckiser, the British company that makes Lysol and Dettol, warned customers on Friday against using disinfectants as treatments.

item.title: Missouri and Kansas Mayors Debated When to End Coronavirus Restrictions
item.description: A sometimes tense conference call among Missouri and Kansas leaders provided a rare look at how discussions about lifting coronavirus restrictions are unfolding nationwide.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: Pedestrians in a deserted Kansas City, Mo., downtown on what would normally have been a busy April workday morning.

item.title: Coronavirus Testing in California: What to Know
item.description: Friday: Testing capacity is still a major hurdle to reopening, but California is getting closer. Also: PG&E’s chief executive said he’ll retire.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: A worker checking in a driver at a drive-through testing site at Cal State University East Bay in Hayward.

item.title: I Used to Make Fun of Silicon Valley Preppers. Then I Became One.
item.description: In tech circles, gearing up for the apocalypse was a cliché. Now it’s a credential.
item.dc:creator: Nellie Bowles
item.media:credit: Bobby Doherty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Why is disaster prep so appealing to techies? Perhaps there is something about getting everything you have overnight that predisposes you to imagine losing it just as quickly.

item.title: Latest Polls: Biden Leads Trump in Key States. But Clinton Led by More.
item.description: While polling shows Joe Biden narrowly ahead in states like Michigan, things looked considerably rosier for Hillary Clinton in many swing states at this point in 2016.
item.dc:creator: Giovanni Russonello
item.media:credit: Michelle Gustafson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Biden at a campaign event in Scranton, Pa., in October.

item.title: Coronavirus, Congress, N.F.L. Draft: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Chris Stanford

item.title: When Life Felt Normal: Your Pre-Pandemic Moments
item.description: Readers share memories, images and videos from before the coronavirus became a pandemic, and reflect on what they mean now.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Wise

item.title: If Joe Biden Needs a Black Woman for Vice President, Who Should It Be?
item.description: Among black leaders close to Joe Biden, a commitment to selecting a woman is not enough. They have publicly and privately pushed him to select a black woman to fuel black voter enthusiasm.
item.dc:creator: Astead W. Herndon
item.media:credit: Curtis Compton/Atlanta Journal-Constitution, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Stacey Abrams and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. appeared at a church service in Selma, Ala., last month. She has been repeatedly mentioned as a potential running mate for Mr. Biden.

item.title: Canceled Spelling Bee? Not if These Siblings Can Help It
item.description: Shobha and Shourav Dasari have organized a national spelling bee after the Scripps tournament was canceled because of the coronavirus pandemic. It will take place online.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.category: Beeline: What Spelling Bees Reveal About Generation Z's New Path to Success (Book)
item.media:description: Shourav Dasari at age 13, during the finals of the 2016 National Spelling Bee, in National Harbor, Md.

item.title: Guerrilla Golfers Sneak Onto Greens Closed by Pandemic
item.description: Half of all golf courses are shut down. But across America — and especially in Florida — renegades are still getting their fix.
item.dc:creator: David Segal
item.media:credit: Angel Valentin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scott Eckert, a golfer in Boca Raton, drafted an online petition to reopen Palm Beach County’s courses. “There is a Bill of Rights,” he said, “and our civil liberties have been trashed.”

item.title: China's Elite Donate Coronavirus Gear to the U.S.
item.description: People and companies with vested interest in sustaining the U.S.-China relationship are stepping in as ties fray between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Nicholas Kulish and David Gelles
item.media:description: Medical personal protective equipment from China being unloaded from a plane in Los Angeles.

item.title: Smithfield Meat Plant Conditions Assailed as Public Nuisance
item.description: A lawsuit filed against a Smithfield Foods plant claims it has created a public nuisance by failing to protect workers from coronavirus infection.
item.dc:creator: Noam Scheiber and Michael Corkery
item.category: United Food and Commercial Workers Union
item.media:description: A Smithfield Foods pork plant in Milan, Mo., is at the center of a legal complaint about working conditions.

item.title: Trump Is Harsh on Immigration. That Doesn’t Mean Biden Has the Latino Vote.
item.description: Some Democrats worry that their party is taking a crucial bloc for granted in 2020.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Medina
item.media:credit: Samuel Corum for The New York Times
item.media:description: Volunteers reciting the Pledge of Allegiance at the start of a Latinos for Trump meeting in Fairfax, Va., in November.

item.title: Trump Muses About Light as Remedy, but Also Disinfectant, Which Is Dangerous
item.description: At a briefing, the president promoted unproven treatments and asked Dr. Deborah Birx if she had heard of the success of sunlight as a tool against viruses.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad and Dan Levin
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at a coronavirus briefing on Thursday. “Supposing we hit the body with a tremendous — whether it’s ultraviolet or just very powerful light,” he said.

item.title: Wall Street Rallies, Bucking Drop in Global Stocks
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Josh Ritchie for The New York Times
item.media:description: AutoNation said in a statement that the money it received from the federal government was intended to go to the 7,000 employees it had furloughed.

item.title: E.U. Waters Down Report on China’s Coronavirus Propaganda: Live Updates
item.description: Belgium said it would start gradually lifting lockdown measures in May.
item.media:description: A Chinese flag on a billboard in Serbia last month.
